REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION OF THE PRESIDENT TO THE BOARD
OF DIRECTORS ON THE PROPOSED SUPPLEMENTARY LOAN TO
THE PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF BANGLADESH FOR THE
BANGLADESH WEST ZONE POWER PROJECT
1. I submit to the Board of Directors, for their con-
sideration and decision, the following Report and Recommendation
on a proposed supplementary loan from the Special Funds
resources of the Bank in an amount in various currencies
equivalent to $4.55 million applied for by the People's Republic
of Bangladesh for the financing of cost overrn of the Bangladesh
West Zone Power Project. The loan would have a term of 40 years,
including a grace period of 10 years, with a service charge of
1 per cent per annum.
I. INTRODUCTION
2. On 17 October 1973 the Bank approved, under the
Special Funds Supplementation Scheme, two loans in various
currencies aggregating $10.45 million to the People's Republic
of Bangladesh for financing the Bangladesh West Zone Power
Project. One loan amounting to $9.25 million was from the
Special Funds resources (Loan No. 141-BAN(SF)) and the other
for $1.20 million from the ordinary capital resources (Loan
No. 142-BAN). These loans were made to meet the foreign
exchange cost of construction of a gas turbine power plant at
Bheramara in the West Zone having a total capacity of 40MW,
spare parts required to overhaul the existing gas turbine
generation plant at Khulna, sub-station and communication
equipment, consulting services and training of staff. The
Borrower is the People's Republic of Bangladesh and the Exe-
cuting Agency, the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB),
under the Ministry of Power, Flood Control and Water Resources.
The loan agreements were signed on 14 November 1973 at the
loans became effective on 6 February 1974. With a view to
imtroving the financial and organizational position of BPDB,
the Bank also approved, aside from the project-oriented con-
sultant services, a provision for consultants on management,
accounting and financial aspects under the Bank's technical
assistance amounting to $250,000 (T/A No. 95).
3. The opening of bids in June 1974 for the 40MW gas
turbine power plant indicated a foreign exchange cost which
exceeded the total amount of the Bank loans. Moreover, the
foreign exchange cost of the spares and equipment provided for
some of the associated facilities in the West Zone is also
expected to increase due to their accelerated deterioration
during the last 18 months, and also due to general price

2 -
escalation. The total foreign exchange component of the Project
is now estimated to have increased by $4.55 million to $15
million. In view of the balance-of-payments difficulties and
non-availability of other alternative sources of financing, the
Government sent a delegation to Manila in September 1974 to
seek a supplementary loan for the Project from the Bank.
Following this request a Peappraisal Mission visited Bangladesh
in October 1974.
4. Formal negotiations for the proposed supplementary
loan were held in Dacc on 18 November 197/ with the authorized
representatives of the Government of the People's Republic of
Bangladesh and the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB).
II. THE ECONOMY
5. The Economic Report on Bangladesh (BAN:Ec-l) was
circulated to the Board in March 1973. Economic data have
been updated following the visits of Bank staff to the country
in July and September 1974. The Basic Data for Bangladesh
are presented in Appendix 1.
6. With a population of 75 million living in an area
of only 141,000 sq. km., Bangladesh faces critical and complex
development problems. The main characteristics of the economy
are the extreme poverty of the people, a very high population
density of more than 500 per sq. km. aggravated by an annual
population growth rate of about 2.5 per cent, a high unemploy-
ment rate of about 25-30 per cent, a literacy rate below 20
per cent, a low life expectancy rate, and low productivity
in various economic sectors. Having a per capita income of
about $80 in 1973, the country is among the world's least
developed countries.
7. Bangladesh is predominantly an agricultural country.
About 90 per cent of the population is rural and about 80 per
cent is engaged in agriculture with substantial underemployment.
The agricultural sector generates nearly 60 per cent of GDP,
with rice being the predominant crop. Raw jute plays a key
role in the economy of Bangladesh, both as the major input for
the country's main industry and as the primary commodityfor
export. Between FY1969/70 and FY1973/74 raw jute and manufac-
tured jute products earned 75 per cent to 90 per cent of
Bangladesh's foreign exchange.

-3-
8. The industrial sector plays a complementary role
to the predominantly agriculture-based economy of the country.
The industrial sector contributes an estimated 8 per cent to
GDP, of which large-scale industries account for about 6 per
cent and the remainder originates in small-scale and cottage
industries. About two-third of all industry is agriculture-
based; the jute and cotton textile industries account for
about 40 per cent of the total industrial value-added and
employ about 60 per cent of the total industrial labor force.
Other agro-basec1 industrial products are tea and leather for
export markets and sugar and tobacco for domestic consumption.
Construction, power and housing contribute another 8 per cent
to GDP. The share of trade, transport and cther organized
services is about 25 per cent.
9. A proper assessment of the overall economic perform-
ance of Bangladesh is made difficult by the deficiencies of
naticnal accounts statistics. Estimated GDP at cistant factor
costs in 1973/74 shows an increase of about 12 per cent over
that of 1972/73. Increases in the output of the agricultural,
industrial and power sectors were 11 per cent, 20 per cent and
33 per cent respectively. It should be noted, however, that
these growth rates were based on 1972/73 records which were
substantially lower than those of 1969/70.	 Production in
general has not yet reached the 1969/70 level.
10. Bangladesh has suffered from consecutive crop
failures since independence as a result of drought, floods and
difficulties in the procurement and distribution of agriculture
inputs. Whereas rice production showed an increase from 99
million tons in 1972/73 to 11.7 million tons in 1973/74, jute
production declined from 6.5 million bales in 1972/73 to 6.0
million bales in 1973/74. The most serious problem confront-
ing the Government has been the continuing shortage of food.
Government stock of food grains have not improve satisfacto-
rily. The shortfalls in local production, compared with
requirements, had to be met by imports which had partly been
made possible through foreign grants. In 1972/73, record
levels of food imports of about 2.8 million tons, compared
with 1.7 million tons in 1973/74, prevented a widely feared

general famine. After the mid-l974 flood disaster, it is
expected that the 1974/75 import requirementof food will
be in order of 2.3-2.5 million tons.
11. Whereas the 1972/73 performance of the industrial
sector was not very satisfactory, in 1973/74, the total
industrial production is estimated to have risen 20 per cent
over the 1972/73 level against a plan target of 30 per cent
but was still below the level attained in 1969/70. Production
of jute textiles has shcwn some improvement but is likely not
to exceed 90 per cent of the 1969/70 production. Some
industries, like newsprint, paper and rayor suffered severely
from the oil crisis, but jute goods benefitted from it in the
form of higher export prices. However 9 export price increases
were negligible, compared with the steep increase in prices of
essential imports, especially food grains, oil and fertilizer.
12. Bangladesh has still not recovered entirely from
the losses during the war in communications, roads and high-
ways, railways, power generating and other infrastrucutre
facilities. The revival of industrial activities would
continue to be affected by the inadequate reconstruction of
the infrastructure facilities.
13. Since independence, and especially during 1972/73
and thereafter, prices of all commodities rose at a much
faster rate than previously. On average, the cost of living
in Dacca, for which an index is available, increased in 1972/
73 by 50 per cent; and by 40 per cent during 1973/74 according
to the Government statistics.
14. Besides imported inflation, which played a much more
important role in stimulating price increases in 1973/74
than in 1972/73, this abnormal situation developed largely
because of the low level of domestic production and internal
distribution deficiencies which left a large gap between the
availability of goods and the demand. Imports could not bridge
the gap adequately. Money supply increased very rapidly in
1972/73 by 43 per cent; but slowed down to 17 per cent in
1973/74.
15. In both 1972/73 and 1973/74 fiscal revenues could
cover only about 80 per cent of current expenditures. Food
subsidies, amounting to Tk.783 million in 1972/73 and to
Tk.963 million in 1973/74, were the main cause for the

5
increase in the current expenditures. To cover partially
the overall budgetary deficits of Tk.4,778 million in 1972/73
and Tk.4,811 million in 1973/74, the Government had to
resort to deficit financing to the extent of Tk.1,611 million
in 1972/73 and Tk.1,771 million in 1973/74. In order to
reduce the 1974/75 deficit, the Government took some measures,
such as introduction of a new import license tax, increase
of railway fares and postal rates, reduction of food subsidies
and agricultural input subsidies. With these measures,
revenues are projected to rise by as much as 50 per cent over
the 1973/74 level. Despite this, the 1974/75 overall budgetary
deficit is estimated at Tk..4,564 million.
16. To a considerable extent, the present severe difficul
ties in the balance payments are the result of unfavorable
external factors. The deficit on current account in the
balance of payments, deteriorated to $561 million in 1973/74
compared with a deficit of $315 million in 1972/73. Besides
large outlays of foreign exchange for food grains, and the
poor export performance	 export volumes in 1973/74 were
lower than in 1972/73	 the most important factor was the
sharp deterioration in the terms of trade. Significant
increases in import prices occurred with respect to major
imports such as food grains, edible oils, fertilizers, crude
oil, petroleum products, raw cotton and cotton yard, leading
to an overall increase of import prices of about 65 per cent
in 1973/74 coirpared with the previous year. On the other
hand price improvements with respect to raw jute and jute
manufactures, the main export items, were less than 4 per cent
for the same period. In addition, there has been a shortfall
in the disbursement of foreign aid. Instead of the expected
Tk.3,520 million, only Tk.3,000 million is estimated to
have been received from foreign sources in 1973/74, forcing
the Government to cut down expenditures under the Annual Plan
by 14 per cent.
17. The balance of payments outlook for 1974/75 is not
promising. Total export of goods and services is estimated
at $410 million but estimated imports of food grains alone
account for $506 million. The deficit on current account for
1974/75 is $1,030 million. This deficit is planned to be
partially financed by $50 million food aid, $160 million
commodity aid, $159 million project aid and the I.NF oil

I.
facility of $45 million. The means for financing the remaining
$650 million still has to be found. Foreign exchange reserves
have been falling sharply in recent months from about $137
million at the end of December 1973 to $38 million at the end
of August 1974, equivalent to about half of one month's
commercial import requirements, considering an estimated total
import volume of about $920 million in 1973/74. At the end
of 1973 Bng1adesh's total outstanding public debt was $834
million,1" of which $355 million were loans from the Govern
ments and $258 million from international organizations. In view
of the July/Septmber	 1974 flood,	 the worst since 1954,
the low foreign exchange reserves and the Government's short-
term commitments, the economic situat:Lon especially during
the next few months, will be very difficult.
18. The present economic situation, however, not only
reflects the series of unfavorable external and domestic deve-
lopments, but also deep-rooted problems in the structure of
the economy. To deal with these difficulties, the Government
announced in November 1973 the First FiveYear Plan (1973/74
to l977/78) having a total outlay of Tk.44,550 million.
Despite some revisions which will be necessary in the light
of international and domestic developments, including the
mid-1974 flood disaster, it is expected that the main prio-
rities - 24 per cent of the outlays for agriculture and 20
per cent for industry	 will be maintained. The program for
the agricultural sector aims to achieve self-sufficiency in
food grain production in the terminal year of the Plan,
mainly through the application of a seedbase technology
consisting of high-yielding varieties of IRRI rice, fertilizers
and irrigation projects. A delay of a few years in reaching
this goal is likely, however. The Government's new Investment
Policy, promulgated in July 19749 is directed mainly towards
increasing the private sector's participation in productive
investments.
19. The prevailing problems call for continuous and
energetic efforts by Government to improve economic adminis-
tration and for increased foreign assistance. After the

Government circulated an Aide Memoire to potential donors,
outlining its foreign exchange difficulties and appealing
for a substantial increase in immedtate financial assistance,
n IBRD-sponsored Aid Group meeting was held in October
1974. During the next few years, Bangladesh's needs for aid
are estimated at about $1 billion a year. If the large
unexploited natural gas resources can be tapped, and if the
exploration for oil in the Bay of Bengal has favorable
results, the outlook of theeccinothy of Bangladesh would charie

III. BANK OPERATIONS IN BANGLADESH
20. The Bank's operations in Bangladesh started in
November 1972.1/ The Bank has so far extended seven loans
aggregating $33.05 million for four projects; three loans
amounting to $11.40 million from its ordinary capital
resourcesa/ and four loans amounting to $21.65 million from
its Special Funds resources. En addition, the Bank has
extended six technical assistance grants totalling $698,000.
Five of the technical assistance grants amounting to $652,000
were in connection with loan projects, principally for
advisory assistance to the institutions executing these
projects. The remaining technical assistance amounting to
$46,000 was for the preparation of a jute seed project. The
sank had also acted as the Executing Agency for the Bangladesh
Energy Survey Inception Study financed by UNDP at a cost of
$50,000. Subsequently, the Bank has also agreed to act as
an Executing Agency for the full-scale Energy Study to be
financed by UNDP estimated to cost at $1.45 million.
21. Appendix 2 shows the current status of the Bank's v
projects in Bangladesh. Two projects (Bangladesh Shilpa
Bank (BSB) and Chittagong Port) are on schedule, although
utilization of the loan to BSE was somewhat slow in the initial
stage. However, the other two projects (Fisheries Development
and West Zone Power) are substantially delayed. Part A of
the Fisheries Development Project is undergoing modification
in the scope of the Project. The West Zone Power Project is
delayed and involves an estimated cost overrun of $4.55
million, for which a supplementary loan is being proposed.
1/ The first mission namely, the EcOflomic-cum-Reconnaisance
Mission, visited Bangladesh from 28 November to 13 December
1972. The country became a member of the Bank in March
1973 and the first loan was extended in June 1973.
2/ Including two loans under the Special Funds Supplementation
Scheme in 1973.

-8-
The completion of the Project is expected by March 1976,
a delay of approximately 15 months.	 In connection with
the four loan projects, consultants under the Bank1s
technical assistance have been provided to assist the
executing agencies in management and financial aspects.
22. At present, besides the proposed supplementary
loan for the West Zone Power Project, four other projects
are under active consideration by the Bank Ear possible
loans. Of these projects,the Fertilizer Project is expected
to meet, together with the production from existing plants,
the countrys entire need for fertilizer up to 1982/83. The
hie Seed Project is envisaged to increase the product-
ivity of the cultivation of jute, the countrys major
export item. Similarly,theRailway Project is expected to
improve the efficiency of the transport system in the
country. The Board papers for Bangladesh Shilpa Rin
Sangstha Project have already been circulated; the Project
is expected to support the rehabilitation and modernization
of the country's industrial sector and contribute to a
higher capacity utilization.
23. Development of the agricultural sector through
irrigation, area development, and fertilizer programs,
aiming mainly to increase the food supply, further improve-
ment and expansion of the transport sector and better
utilization and amintenance of the existing power generating
facilities are expected to be the focus of the Bank'
operations in 1975.
IV. THE PROJECT
24. A report entitled "Reappraisal of the West Zone
Power Project in Bang1adesh (Report No. BAN-Ap 3a) is
circulated herewith.
25. The power system of Bangladesh suffered consiclera-
ble damage during the war of 1971. Although generation
facilities were not directly damaged, lack of spare parts,
maintenance and overhaul seriously affected their perform-
ance. Transmission and distribution facilities were
seriously damaged. Power demand fell considerably and the

peak demand dropped from 223MW to 30MW. A reconstrucdon
program and temporary repairs for immediate restoration
of the power supply enabled the return to pre-indepen-
dence generation levels of 535MW; the total generation
capacity in the public sector presently stands at
around 586MW. However, recurrent power failures created
considerable losses in industrial production, which now
consumes about 70 per cent of total power used.
26. The Government allocated Tk.4,235 million for
development outlay of the power sector in the First Five-
Year Plan; this constitutes 9.5 per cent of the total
development outlay. In 1973/74, a total of Tk.428.9
million (including a foreign exchange component of the
equivalent of Tk.l82.7 million) accounting for 10.6 per
cent of the total development outlay was planned.
However, due to resource constraint, the provision had to
be reduced to Tk.359..8 (including foreign exchange compo-
nent of the equivalent of Tk.150 million). In view of the
financial constraints, the physical target anticipated
in the Annual Development Plan could not be achieved.
In the 1974/75 Annual Development Plan, the power sector
was allocated Tk 630 million (with a foreign exchange
component equivalent to Tk.212 million) or about 12 per
cent of the total development outlay of Tk.5,250 million.
This is the fourth largest sectoral allocation after
flood control and water resources, transport (each with
15.2 per cent) and industries (13.5 per cent). The main
emphasis is placed on the completion of ongoing projects,
which include the West Zone Power Project.
27. The purpose of the Project is to help the West
Zone system meet the projected load growth and to permit
a more orderly and efficient use of other generation
facilities by supplying peaking and stand-by capacity,
and to supply industries in the West Zone with reliable
and adequate energy.

28. The schedule of Project implementation envisaged
at the time of appraisal in May 1973 was based on the tender
documents for the turnkey contract for the gas turbine power
plant which were prepared in 1969 and was prepared assuming
that they required only limited modification to specifications
and other items. It was therefore expected that these tender
documents, and also the invitation letter to prospective
consultants, could be finalized and issued by September
1973, and the contracts with the consultants and the supplier
signed by December 1973. However, on account of BPDB's in-
adequate experience in undertaking work of this nature and
its unfamiliarity with Bank procedures, issuance of these
documents was considerably delayed. The contract for con-
sultant services and that with the lowest evaluated bidder
were signed in November 1974.
29. Following the receipt and evaluation of bids for
the 40MW gas turbine power plant, it was found that the
foreign exchange funds available under the Bank loans were
insufficient to finance the full foreign exchange cost of
the Project. Similarly, the accelerated deterioration of
associated facilities in operation during the last 18 months
together with the price escalation is expected to increase
the foreign exchange cost of spare parts and equipment.
30. In order that a contract for the gas turbine
station could be negotiated and finalized with the lowest
evaluated bidder before the expiry of bid validity on 30
September 1974, the Government sought the Banks approval to ne-
gotiate and award the contract even though the bid value
exceeded the amount of the Bank loans. Subsequent to the
Government?
s request, a delegation consisting of represen-
tatives of the Government and BPDB officials together with
the Project consultant visited the Bank from 18 to 25
September 1974 and held discussions with Bank staff. Based
on these discussions and Bank staffts recommendations, the
Bank concurred with the above request to negotiate and
finalize a contract with the lowest evaluated bidder on the
understanding that such concurrence would not in any manner
increase the Bank? s commitment beyond what it had already under-
taken under the loans sanctioned earlier. It was also
decided that the Project should be reappraised, and if
found satisfactory, a supplementary loan would be recommended
to the Board for consideration (see Board Information
Paper IN:95-74 dated 11 November 1974).

- 11 -
31.	 A reappraisal of the Project in 0.ctober 1974
indicated that $4.55 million would be needed to meet the
overrun in the foreign exchange cost. The main component
of the cost overrun is the increase in the cost of the
4OM1 gas turbine plant which accounts for $4.00 million.
The total cost of the Project is estimated to have increased
from $17.5 million to $25 million, of which $15 million is
the foreign exchange component, as against $10.45 million
originally estimated.
32.	 The benefit accruing from the Project remains
unchanged, and the simple cycle gas turbine generators pro-
vided under the Project continue to be the least cost source
of power for the West Zone in the present circumstances.
Taking into account the changes in the capital and,operating
costs, projected load growth and tariff revision,1 the
economic rate of return of the Project is estimated at 5
per cent compared with 12 per cent at the time of appraisal
of the Project in May 1973. However, with a further moderate
increase in tariff of about 10 per cent,the rate of return
would improve to about 12 per cent. It is expected that
tariff revision of a greater magnitude than 10 per cent
could be introduced in the light of the finding of  the Bank
consultants in the near future.
33.	 Although certain management and operating problems
pointed out by the Bank's Appraisal Mission in May 1973 still
exist, the Government and BPDB have undertaken important steps
aimed at streamlining the management and organization of BPDB.
The four-member Board of BPDB has been made fully functional
and a full-time Chairman has been appointed - who is also the
Chief Executive of BPDB. With a view to delegating authority,
BPDB proposes to reorganize regional offices. These measures
are regarded as interim by the Government and it has assured
the Reappraisal Mission that, when the management expert
under the Bank's technical assistance is appointed, further
modification and improvement would be considered in the light
of the recommendation made by him.
1/ The tariff rate referred to includes the 100 per cent
increase which has been approved by the Government
and to be implemented on 1 December 1974.

- 12 -
34. The Bank stresses the importance of maintenance
requirements -- this being the most neglected area of BPDB's
operation - - and BPDB is required under the loan provisions
to formulate a comprehensive maintenance program for the
West Zone facilities by June 1975. After this program is
formulated, the Covnment and BPDB will consider suitable
action in consultation with the Bank and other related
agencies regarding possible finance for implementation of
the program.
35. The financial position of BPDB has not improved
in the past 12 months. The increase in fuel prices has
aggravated the situation. In order to improve the financial
position of BPDB, the Government has agreed to take the
following measures: (i) tariff increase, (ii) reduction of
the level of accounts receivable and (iii) conversion of
long-term debt from the Government into equity by BPDB. As
an interim measure, the Bank was assured by the Government
that a 100 per cent tariff increa3e will become effective
on 1 December 1974 and accounts receivable will be reduced
to a level of about four months sales by the end of 1975.
The Government and BPDB further assured that they would take
measures to improve the financial position of BPDB, in
consultation with the Bank, when the recommendations of the
Bank-financed consultants are available.
36. The Project remains technically feasible and des-
pite the increase in cost, economically justified and suitable
for Bank financing. In view of the critical economic situa-
tion and difficult balance of payment position, the proposed
loan in the amount of $4.55 million is recommended from the
Bank rs Special Funds resources,
37. The proceeds of the Bank loan are intended to be
made available to BPDB by the Government at an interest rate
of 7,5 per cent, to be repaid over the 25 years. The terms
of the relending arrangements will be subject to review by
the Bank and the Government at the time of the overall
financial review, following the completion of the work of
the Financial and Accounting consultants.

V. LEGAL INSTRUMENTS AND AUTHORITY
39.	 Drafts of the following loan documents are cir-
culated herewith:
(i) Loan Agreement (Special Operations)
between the Government of the People's
Republic of Bangladesh and the Bank;
and

- 14 -
(ii) Project Agreement (Special Operations)
between the Bank and BPDB.
The Banks Special Operations Loan Regulations dated 5 May
1969 are incorporated in the draft Loan Agreement (Special
Operations) subject to the modifications referred to in
Section 1.01 of the draft Loan Agreement.
40. Under the constitution of the People's Republic
of Bangladesh, the Government is authorized to borrow from
the Bank. Under the BPDB Order, BPDB is empowered to enter
into and implement its obligations under the Project
Agreement.
41. I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply
with the Articles of Agreement of the Bank.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
42. I recommend that the Board approve the proposed
supplementary loan in terms of the following resolution:
"RESOLVED:
That the Bank shall make a loan from its
Special Funds resources to the People's
Republic of Bengladesh in an amount in various
currencies equivalent to Four Million Five
Hundred Fifty Thousand United States Dollars
(US$4,550,000) to mature on and prior to
1 June 2015 and to bear service charge at the
rate of one per cent (l7) per annum and to be
upot such other ternis and conditions as shall
be substantially in accordance with the terms
and conditions set forth in the form of Loan
Agreement between the People's Republic of
Bargj.adesh and the Bank and the form of Project
Agreement between the Bank and the Bangladesh
Power Development Board which have been pre-
sented to this meeting."
SHIRO INOUE
President
